newsitem.title: CANADA: Pacific air mass to spare Canada Prairies of frost.
newsitem.headline: Pacific air mass to spare Canada Prairies of frost.

text.p: A Pacific air mass should spare Canada's Prairies of a frost, a meteorologist said.

"Looks like for the next several days, we're in a pattern that's not conducive to frost with an air mass coming in from the Pacific, rather than the Arctic," said Environment Canada meteorologist Clarence Spelchak.
Forty five percent of wheat, barley, canola, oats, flax and rye were seeded on the Prairies as of Tuesday, Canadian Wheat Board said.
Wheat needs 90 to 100 days to mature. There are 100 days from May 23 to August 31.
Barley needs 60 to 90 days to mature, oats 85 to 88 days, flax 85 to 100 days, Argentine canola 92 to 102 days, Polish canola 73 to 83 days and field peas 90 to 100 days.
"If skies stay clear, maybe Sunday or Monday morning you'll see lows of +1.0 or +2.0 Celsius," Spelchak said.
The average spring frost season for the Prairies ends between May 20 and 28, CWB weather and crop surveillance director Paul Bullock said.
Lows of -4.0 Celsius must last four hours to kill wheat but spring crops can be reseeded and may reach maturity in time for fall harvest, Bullock said.
